formulas.title: Formula (extracted text)
formulas.raw: Area of a kite from diagonals Let \(d_1\) and \(d_2\) be the lengths of the diagonals of a kite. If they are perpendicular, then the area is \[ A = \frac{d_1 \cdot d_2}{2}. \] Geometrically, the diagonals split the kite into four right triangles. The total area is the sum of the areas of these triangles.

formulas.title: Formula (extracted text)
formulas.raw: Side–angle formula For each triangle, \[ A_{\triangle} = \frac{1}{2} a b \sin(\theta), \] and there are two such triangles, so \[ A_{\text{kite}} = 2 \cdot A_{\triangle} = 2 \cdot \frac{1}{2} a b \sin(\theta) = a b \sin(\theta). \]
